GSD.description: When running Apache Tomcat 7.0.0 to 7.0.79 on Windows with HTTP PUTs enabled (e.g. via setting the readonly initialisation parameter of the Default to false) it was possible to upload a JSP file to the server via a specially crafted request. This JSP could then be requested and any code it contained would be executed by the server.

cisa.gov.shortDescription: When running Apache Tomcat on Windows with HTTP PUTs enabled, it is possible to upload a JSP file to the server via a specially crafted request. This JSP could then be requested and any code it contained would be executed by the server.
cisa.gov.vulnerabilityName: Apache Tomcat on Windows Remote Code Execution Vulnerability

description_data.value: When running Apache Tomcat 7.0.0 to 7.0.79 on Windows with HTTP PUTs enabled (e.g. via setting the readonly initialisation parameter of the Default to false) it was possible to upload a JSP file to the server via a specially crafted request. This JSP could then be requested and any code it contained would be executed by the server.

This JSP could then be requested and any code it contained would be executed by the server.
advisories.not_impacted: All versions before 7.0.0, all versions starting from 7.0.79
advisories.title: Unrestricted Upload of File with Dangerous Type

advisories.affected_versions: All versions starting from 7.0 up to 7.0.51, all versions starting from 7.0.54 up to 7.0.77, version 7.0.79
